thread.title_full: Cory Bernardi and Penny Wong debate same-sex marriage at National Press Club | The Advertiser

author: Network Writers, with AAP
title: Cory Bernardi and Penny Wong debate same-sex marriage at National Press Club |
text:
OUTSPOKEN Liberal Senator Cory Bernardi has gone head-to-head with Labor Senator Penny Wong over same-sex marriage.
Senator Wong told the National Press Club debate that if the Liberal Party provided a free vote “we are closer now to succeeding on same-sex marriage than we have ever been”.
She said if a vote did go ahead and was defeated the community of supporters would “not go away on this issue”.
“The principle of equality is something we do hold dear and I think most Australians in respect of this matter agree,” she said.
Senator Bernardi said if a plebiscite showed that the majority of states were in favour of same-sex marriage he would not argue against it.
He said same-sex couples were not discriminated against under current laws.
“I just don’t see there is any need to redefine one of our longest-standing institutions to mean something it has never meant,” he said.
Marriage debate is about real people: Wong 2:23 Play video
Penny Wong says legalising same sex marriage will make a profound difference to gay and lesbian couples.
Sky News 29 Jul 2015 News Senator Bernardi said his party should have a clear position on same-sex marriage.
“I think it is in our interests to maintain the status quo,” he said.
“If people in my party disagree with that, they are free to vote otherwise.
“I just don’t buy into this argument that just because something appears popular it’s the right thing to do for the country.”
Senator Wong said the institution of marriage had evolved and it was a basic right of same-sex couples to be treated equally by the law.
“Women once were denied the vote, were paid less and had to resign from the public service once married,” Senator Wong said.
“The children of Aboriginal Australians were once taken away. Times have changed.
“Misogyny and discrimination haven’t been eliminated, but they are no longer entrenched in law, and the institution of marriage has evolved, too.
“We are your brothers and your sisters, your sons and your daughters, your friends and your fellow Australians, and this is a debate about us. A debate about rights, a debate about intimate and personal relationships, a debate about the people we love.”
Right-wing Liberal warrior Cory Bernardi took on left-wing Labor frontbencher Penny Wong in a debate streamed live on Advertiser.com.au. Source: The Advertiser
Senator Bernardi said the campaign was not about equality — it was about redefining one of the fundamental pillars of society.
“I believe, and I think it’s crystal clear, this campaign is not about equality, but it’s about personal desire and self-interest of a vocal minority,” Senator Bernardi said.
He said those against same-sex marriage were painted as “bigots”.
“We’re called homophobes or worse and on the name-calling, once again it’s simply another well-known propaganda technique designed to silence an alternative voice.
“I believe it’s crude, it smacks of hypocrisy and intolerance, but it is very effective in silencing many from sharing their view.”
He said he feared that legalising same-sex marriage would open the floodgates to redefine other relationships, such as polyamory and bestiality.
“I can’t and I will not deny that some same-sex couples make much, much parents than some married heterosexual couples,” he said.
“However, it doesn’t change the general principle that the ideal is still a child being raised by their married mother and father.”
Senator Wong said she would not be willing to support multi-member marriages and that businesses didn’t have any need to fear discrimination if they were against same-sex marriage.
Live coverage (Frame content direct link: http://embed.scribblelive.com/Embed/v7.aspx?Id=1403808&ThemeId=16707 .)
The South Australian pair met at the National Press Club at lunchtime to go head to head over whether Australia should legalise gay marriage.
Senator Bernardi caused outrage when he linked same-sex legalisation to the acceptance of bestiality .
Senator Wong — who is in a same-sex relationship with partner Sophie Allouache — has decried the extreme language used by marriage equality opponents.
The debate came after it was revealed some Coalition MPs were pushing for same-sex marriage to be put to a national vote.
Same-sex marriage supporters believe a plebiscite , which has the support of Social Services Minister Scott Morrison, could delay a law change.
Opposition Leader Bill Shorten announced at Labor’s national conference at the weekend he would legislate for same-sex marriage within 100 days of government.
The party also agreed to bind MPs to vote for the Marriage Act change — rather than have a conscience vote — if laws had not been enacted by the end of the next term.
The national ballot would mean setting aside current talks on a cross-party bill, which could come to parliament as early as next month.
Originally published as Bernardi vs Wong: Who won the gay marriage debate?
